Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2011 10:39AM AimeeMac wrote: Ducky - I felt just like you at the start of rads. 33 seemed like an impossible number, and I felt hopeless, angry and scared. I have all of my appt. dates and times on a sheet stuck to my memo board, and every day when I get home I mark another day off with a highlighter. Just finished 14 of 33 today, and while it still feels like a giant mountain, I can see my way to the top, and then it is all downhill. At 14 days, I am only a little pink and haven't really had fatigue to speak of. I am a fairly big breasted woman, so I take care to make sure my "underboob" stays as dry as possible after putting the aloe gel on it, then tuck my t-shirt between my flabby boob and my abdomen to make sure there is no skin against skin. Not a pretty picture but I am trying to avoid any complications there.  I've said before how this is emotionally tougher for me than chemo, and am still trying to figure out why that is. The chemo room was a busy place with lots of people, and for me it wasn't a stressful experience, but rads is "me against the machine" all alone in the room. God, I can't wait for this to be over!

Posts.Content: May 4, 2011 05:07AM AimeeMac wrote: Wondered if anyone else is on week 5 of rads? Don't want to think about blisters - it's getting uncomfortable enough as it is.

Posts.Content: Mar 21, 2014 08:54AM AimeeMac wrote: Carolben, I think I understand your onc's philosophy better than mine. I am really thinking about getting a second opinion, but am seeing the interventional radiologist this afternoon to better understand the ablation issue. From what I gather about the procedure, it is similar but a bit more invasive than a biopsy, but the needle/wire carries a current that pretty much fries the tumor.  In terms of the chemo, it just seems to me that with millions of cancer cells now running free through my bloodstream chemo might kill off a lot of them and keep them from meandering to other organs. Plus, I think I tolerated chemo pretty well (Taxotere/cytoxan), and it sounds like there are fewer side effects with a singular chemo protocol. It's so great that you and your son have such a good relationship. I have two daughters, 23 and 29, and a son who turned 26 in January. He is moving back home at the end of the month more due to job loss, but has really been trying to help with things around the house as well as with keeping our spirits up. He keeps me from being too morbid. Typical scenario yesterday, in one of my low points I asked him if he would want to give my engagement ring to his girlfriend Hollie someday after I'm gone. He replied "shut the F up mom - you're not going anywhere soon."

Posts.Content: Jun 12, 2011 08:31PM AimeeMac wrote: lorelh Where are you having your treatment? How many rads are you having? When you meet with the RO they will probably go over your pathology report and he or she will give you information about radiation, including SEs, the likely (burning, fatigue), and the very unlikely (lung damage, broken rib). Your RO will cover what your treatment will consist of, and you will be scheduled for your simulation appt, where you will get measured and maybe tattooed (not a big deal) or have taped marks. The wierdest thing for me was having so many people looking at my boob in one day, and all the pictures they took of my boob at different angles, and my face (they always had my face and report on a computer screen when it was my turn for verification.) In terms of questions, I would just make sure that you feel comfortable with your RO, but you will probably be seeing the radiation nurses and technicians a lot more frequently.. Usually you see the RO once a week, but I had much more interaction with the nurses. They were the ones I talked to when I needed prescriptions for anti-anxiety meds and for ambien. They will also give you prescriptions (or free samples) of the lube products they recommend. I used an aloe gel they gave me, as well as aquaphor, but each RO has their own recommended products. Please PM me if you have more questions or just need to vent. I personally founds rads more emotionally difficult.

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2011 12:18PM AimeeMac wrote: Proud Mom - I echo what MaryMeg has to say (although I couldn't do it as eloquently as she). It's okay not to be brave and always put on the happy face. This sucks big time and it's okay to say it does. It's hard for many of us to say we can't do it all as we used to, and to ask for help is not within our nature, as we are the ones who are always helping others. I have come to realize that telling people what you need in terms of help is a gift to them, as so many want to do something and they are helpless as to what that might be. so if you were to ask a friend to do something specific for you, it gives them a way to help. I have a friend who brings me my favorite caramel macchiato on the day she starts work late, and we have a few moments to chat. I am not up for lots of company, but those 30 minutes are a godsend, and my connection to the outside world. My sister has pledged to bring us dinner on my chemo days, and I am already looking forward to that this coming Thursday. I think crying is a healing process, and I put on sad country songs and let it go. While my hair was falling out I played "skin" by Rascal Flatts and cried my eyes out, but felt better afterward. when I was first diagnosed, I played Martina McBride's "anyway" and again the crying was therapeudic. I still very guilty on the days when my husband comes home and I tell him I haven't done a thing all day but sit, sleep, or take a long shower and nap. He asks me "did you heal?" and when I say yes, he tells me I accomplished all I needed to today. He is my rock. I also try to keep a sense of humor with my kids, so they know that while this sucks, we don't have to be afraid of talking about it. I wondered how my adult son, who recently moved back home, would deal with my newly bald head, but when he walked by me sitting on the couch and said "I'm sorry Superman keeps thwarting all your evil plans Mom" I knew he was okay. :)

Posts.Content: Nov 18, 2011 08:16PM AimeeMac wrote: Hi everyone! So good to see Mary Meg posting again - I'm sure many of us where wondering when we'd hear from you again. I passed my 1 year diagnosis day on 11-11-11 and had a NED follow up mammogram a year to the day of the one that changed everything. Been back to work since the end of March, but grounded from my flying job during radiation. Knew I was BAA-ACK once I started flying again. Feel like I am maybe 90% back, but I know that chemo brain is a real thing, and not a joke. I wonder sometimes if disclosing to my boss that I forget more than I remember sometimes would be the worst thing I could do in my job or might offer some disability-related job security. Not going to take the chance right now of talking about it. I had a very disconcerting appt. with my oncologist, who's follow up plan for me is left side mammo every 6 months and both sides every year. No scans unless I have symptoms. Her rationale? My type of BC (triple negative) has only a 3% chance of recurring in the breast, and once it's found outside the breast it's no longer curable and at that point diagnosis wouldn't alter my length of survival. I know that that is true but still sounds like pretty cruel logic. (I plan on faking symptoms every 6 months or so.) I was freaking out for way too long with back pains that were mild  but wouldn't go away. Talked my regular dr. into ordering an MRI, which came back clear (and after that the pain seemed to go away!) Am back to being in a different town each week leading group trainings in front of rooms of people who at this point think that my short hair is "cute." Honestly, it's almost back to the length it used to be, only a different texture. It is hard to believe the difference a year makes, and how now I can go several hours at a time without thinking about BC. Hopefully some day soon entire days will go by that way!  I hope all of you are doing well and feeling confident about the future. Would love to hear from you all.

Posts.Content: Jul 17, 2011 11:49PM AimeeMac wrote: I am 19 weeks PFC, and today my first chemo curl started. It looks like a tiny little horn of hair on my right side. It looks pretty ridiculous, actually. It's probably the first of many, and I've never in my life had curly hair, I won't complain. Today I looked back on my pictures with zero hair, and I am just so thankful for anything now. Like many of you have said, it seemed like it would never start coming in, and I must have looked in the mirror 100 times a day (which is about 99 more than usual) waiting for the first sprouts. This past week I was at a meeting in Tempe with my training team (about 15 people) from all over the country. They all knew about my situation, but only two had seen me since diagnosis and none had seen me without a wig. The first and second day of the meeting I kept it on, but when the group went out to dinner on Tuesday night, I decided to take a leap of faith and go "topless." There were a few startled looks at first, but after that, I got a lot of honest (not pitiful) smiles, and one of the women took me aside and said she like me better without the wig!

Posts.Content: May 31, 2011 10:42AM AimeeMac wrote: slcst12- My last chemo ws 3-10, and my hair has finallystarted to come in a lot more now (11 weeks). My avatar picture is at about 8 weeks, The first 8 or 9 weeks were a horrible watch and wait time, and for me losing hair has been the worst part of this whole mess (I know that sounds vain, but I really only felt sick when I looked at my bald self.) I work at home, and found I had better days when I put on a wig, even when I was by myself. but a funny thing happened a few weeks ago, My husband said he likes me better without the wig, because "it is me" as he says. It made me feel more powerful in some strange way. This weekend is our local Relay for Life, and I signed up to walk the Survivor Lap which begins the event. Pretty sure I feel comfortable now to do that topless! Don't worry, it will come in. I'm going to Vegas at the end of August for my daughter's 21st birthday, and I plan on leaving the wigs at home by then!

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2012 09:33PM AimeeMac wrote: Hope you don't mind me jumping on your board for a bit, but I just wanted to send all you ladies some words of encouragement. Today is my 1st "Chemoversary," and your postings sound so very familiar. At the time, it was impossible to imagine there would ever be a day when I would have a full head of hair again and be back to work full time. So please, hang in there and even though it might get worse before it gets better, when the SEs and the fears fill your body and brain and you wonder how you will get through the next hour, know that there will be a time not far away that you will look back on this relatively short period of your life and hardly believe that it happened. I am not minimizing what you are all going through, or patting myself on the back, but just want to reassure you that you will make it through this. Hang in there.

Posts.Content: Mar 27, 2014 08:58PM AimeeMac wrote: Hi, new to the group with lots of questions. I received my Stage IV diagnosis at the beginning of the month, have 5 nodules in my back but only 2 lighting up on the PET scan. My doctor wants to take them out with radiofrequency ablation (basically like a biopsy with radio frequency that pretty much fries them). And I'm cool with that. BUT she says that other than that I am asymptomatic and she wants to hold off on chemo for as long as possible - months or even YEARS and just watch and see if any of the other nodule are cancerous. She says she can't prolong my life but can prolong the length of time I don't feel sick. I am going for a second opinion from another treatment center. I also have an option to participate in a Phase II clinical trial that combines Abraxane and Avastin, but the side effects sound so numerous and awful. I handled chemo okay the first time through. Have any of you had experience with these two, either singularly or in combo - and what kind of SEs to you have?
Posts.Title: Triple Negative Stage IV Renae64 thrivingmama

Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2014 02:45AM AimeeMac wrote: Sorry I misspoke. The nodules are in my lungs in three different areas. I am going in on Thursday for a second opinion from Seattle Cancer Care Alliance. I am also talking with them about a Phase II clinical Trial combining Abraxane and Avastin. I am also scheduled on Friday for the radiofrequency ablation for the first of the two malignant nodules. I feel very good right now, no issues and you wouldn't know I was sick to look at me. The thought of going back on chemo, losing my hair again and all the SEs, it feels like once I start down this path again I will never feel well another day of my life.  Feeling so conflicted right now.

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2015 11:56PM AimeeMac wrote: Hi Lucy, I haven't been on these boards for several months, and have been thinking about you and our text conversations. Decided to get back on and here you are! I am in the middle of applying for SSDI, and to echo the other ladies, a stage IV diagnosis is pretty much an automatic approval that is pushed through in a matter of weeks instead of months (after they get your medical records). I am a few years younger than you, so don't know about the medicare stuff. I was also told that your benefits would start 5 months after your last day of work, and you will retroactively receive benefits if you have been off work longer than that. I went out on disability May 3rd, so will be paid for November forward. However, I have been receiving LTD benefits during this time, so I think I have to hand that check over to Liberty Mutual to recompensate them for what they have been paying me. I am glad to hear that the clinical trial we talked about several months ago seems to have been good for you. I have had gamma knife for mets to the brain that worked on the 9 originals, but two new ones have shown up so we are taking a look at those at the end of March. I have a CT on Monday with results on Wednesday for the lungs. Fingers crossed on those; they seem to still be growing slowly. I'll be keeping you in my thoughts and prayers. Aimee
